title: Oil Spill's Economic Impact
name: Oil Spill's Economic Impact
description: An in-depth map portraying the far-reaching econoimic impact of the Gulf oil spill.

properties.name: Baldwin County, AL
properties.description: In Baldwin County, tourism supports over 41,000 jobs with payrolls totaling almost $1 billion. Over 4.5 million people visit the area annually and spend about $2.3 billion in the local area, contributing over $100 million to Alabama’s general and education trust funds.  Most of this spending occurs between Memorial Day and Labor Day.  Today, tourism is off 50% and the trend is downward.  Retail stores and restaurants are reporting that sales are off 70%. The fishing industry is essentially closed. Most of the 41,000 jobs are in very small businesses, many of which have been family-owned for generations.

properties.name: Bayou La Batre, AL
properties.description: Pastor Dan Brown, of the Anchor Assembly of God in Boyou la Batre, Alabama, is seeking compensation of $50,000 to cover an anticipated loss of income over the next year. Pastor Brown claims that the lost income provided by fishermen, shrimpers and oystermen – who are now out of work because of the oil spill – is down $12,000 and he anticipates a further $38,000 "loss." The pastor is seeking financial restitution from BP, justifying his claim by likening his church to a business and explaining to the Telegraph: "You can't tithe what you don't have. We're fighting for our lives just like a business."

properties.name: Biloxi, MS
properties.description: Biloxi Mayor A.J. Holloway told the oil spill commission that the disaster has had a devastating impact on his city's shrimpers, though some are now getting paid to do clean-up work by BP: "Last year, on opening day of shrimp season, we had 230 shrimp boats in Mississippi waters. This year, shrimp season opened a few days early at the beginning of June, to get ahead of the oil. We had 67 boats on opening day. The rest were working for BP."

properties.name: Fort Walton Beach, FL
properties.description: Realizing the negative trend related to tourism, Fort Walton Beach hotels, much like in Panama City Beach, have been forced to drastically lower their rates by 23% in order to salvage some business.

properties.name: Franklin, LA
properties.description: AmeriPure Processing Company's owner, Pat Fahey, just recently closed his oyster processing plant indefinitely, resulting in the laying off of 60 employees. A year ago, Fahey would process 1,000 bags of oysters a day but now 250 bags is considered a success. In May alone, Fahey's plant was down a substantial amount, around $195,000. Expecting similar results in the following month, he had no choice but to close the plant's doors until things improve, leaving the future of the company very much in the balance.

properties.name: Galveston, TX
properties.description: The oil spewing in the Gulf has made its way to Galveston, TX, impacting one of the largest cruise lines in the world, Carnival Cruise. Although business has been normal since the spill, the oil and tar balls are beginning to encroach upon the cruise routes, pressuring Carnival to make minor directional alterations. At this point Carnival can avoid the heavily impacted regions, but as the oil spreads throughout the entire Gulf coast, its future operations in the region remain shrouded in ambiguity.

properties.name: Grand Isle, LA
properties.description: Residents of Grand Isle are used to seeing their small town of 1,500 swell to a staggering 10,000 when the tourist season begins. The locals embrace the influx of tourism each year -- moreover, they depend on it. Unfortunately, the oil spill has claimed the economic lifeblood of Grand Isle, with locals counting a mere 100 tourists this season, reports USA Today. Instead the town's hotels are filled with military personnel and contract workers who are here to help with the relief effort.

properties.name: Gulf County, FL
properties.description: Gulf County is feeling the impact from the oil spill, particularly in its tourism. "We're not getting the phone calls,"  Tim Kerigan, tourism director for Florida's Gulf County, told McClatchy Newspapers. Summer home rentals are off a staggering 80 percent since the rig explosion in late April.

properties.name: Gulfport, MS
properties.description: Gulfport, like many other Gulf coast cities, relies on tourism to keep the town's businesses profitable. As expected, its economy has gone into a tailspin since the Deepwater Horizon oil rig exploded in late April. Kevin Drum, executive director of Mississippi Gulf Coast Golf Association, which promotes golf tourism in the three Coast counties, said of the current economic circumstance: “We were going to get back to pre-Katrina numbers this year,” he told the Miami Herald. Instead, he’s seeing far fewer than the normal 30 to 50 requests a day for quotes on golf packages; some days he gets none. The loss to area golf courses, hotels and restaurants will be $12 million if the industry waits until spring to file claims for lost business."

properties.name: Hamilton County, FL
properties.description: With 70 percent of yearly revenue for Gulf counties coming in June through September and  hotel bookings down 62 percent, even a North Florida county like Hamilton will be feeling the economic impact from the oil spill. The state is expected to lose $11 billion in economic activity and lose an estimated 195,000 jobs.

properties.name: Hopedale, LA
properties.description: The pier in Hopedale, LA has consistently been a hot spot for oyster fisherman, but this year, like many other coastal Gulf cities and towns, their catch is half of what it was a year ago with no sign that it will get any better.

properties.name: Houma, LA
properties.description: The shrimping season in Houma has come to an end -- and there is very little to show for it. The Louisiana Department of Wildlife and Fisheries announced Saturday that shrimping Zone 2, which includes waters from the eastern shore of the Mississippi River's South Pass to the western shore of Vermilion Bay and Southwest Pass at Marsh Island, were to shut down Monday, July 6th at 6 a.m. Hundreds of Houma fishermen could not even make an attempt at salvaging the harvesting season, remaining dockside due to the oil spill.

properties.name: Jackson, MS
properties.description: A recent University of Southern Mississippi study said the oil spill could cost Jackson, Harrison and Hancock counties nearly $120 million combined in the tourism and service sectors.

properties.name: Lafitte, LA
properties.description: Lafitte in Jefferson Parish is yet another example of a shrimping town that finds itself in dire straits following the oil spill.  Nunez Seafood, established in 1972, is one of many seafood companies that will not bring in a single catch this season. Randy Nunez, who took over the business that was started by his father Jules, told Fox-8 News that he had no choice but to lay off almost every one of his employees after the spill, retaining only one employee throughout the endeavor. In years prior to the oil spill, Nunez Seafood had an average haul of 50 to 60 pounds of shrimp per day.

properties.name: Lafourche Parish, LA
properties.description: In the wake of the oil spill, Lafourche Parish President Charlotte Randolph has said the oil spill will likely result in a 40 percent decrease in revenue. An omen of the forthcoming economic climate, Lafourche collected $5.2 million in sales-tax income in April, a decrease of 11.9 percent from the previous year. Lafourche Council Chairman Daniel Lorraine said of the situation: “We just have to play it by ear,” adding “We’ll just have to wait and see how it plays out” in an interview with the Daily Comet.

properties.name: New Orleans, LA
properties.description: P&J Oyster Co. in New Orleans, a family-owned and operated company for 134 years, has already laid off 11 workers and may go under, owner Sal Sunseri told the oil spill commission.

properties.name: Orange Beach, AL
properties.description: Known for its beautiful beaches and fun atmosphere, Orange Beach was a popular destination. Ordinarily, Brett Robinson Gulf Shores Vacation Condo Rentals would have 98% of its 2,100 condos rented out to vacationers, however, this year they are happy to have 40% rented. The town's leadership has taken a decisively pessimistic view to the current situation. Gulf Shores Mayor Robert Craft told WBUR, regarding the current state of Gulf Shores: "It's really sad because there's nobody here, and there's certainly no excitement. The lack of hope and enthusiasm and optimism that permeates this community is just really depressing."In an effort to bring tourism back to Orange Beach and Gulf Shores, Jimmy Buffett recently played a concert at his sister Lucy's restaurant, Lulu's.

properties.name: Panama City Beach, FL
properties.description:
Panama City Beach has yet to be hugely affected (hotels have lowered their rates by an average of 11%) by the lack of tourism from the oil spill, but they are anticipating a significant drop-off in the next few months. "Normally
this time of year, families especially, will book for a whole week, and they
make those plans two months ago, three months ago. Now they are not making
those plans that early. And when they do come they are only staying 2 or 3 days
or the weekend," a local hotel manager told WJHG, adding that the Chateau Hotel down the road is seeing the same trends.

properties.name: Pensacola Beach, FL
properties.description: Marinas in Pensacola Beach, FL are beginning to empty as worried sailors move their boats to safer waters. As oil spreads throughout the Gulf, boat owners are fearful that the oil will ruin the boats' motors. Additionally, sailors are restricted by oil booms blocking popular harbors and inlets, greatly limiting their ability to even use their boats as they please.

properties.name: Pensacola Beach, FL
properties.description: It is not just hotel cancellations that are rampant in the Pensacola area. Sometimes called "the Las Vegas of beach weddings," Pensacola Beach wedding cancellations are becoming a regular occurrence. "It's not just me hurting: it's the DJs, caterers, photographers, everyone involved," wedding planner Darrin Land told the AP. He said he's lost $12,000 since news of the oil threat began in late April. "Sixty percent of my beach weddings are canceling. This is worse than a hurricane because we don't know what is going to happen."With weddings encompassing such a large variety of services such as catering, photography and hotels among dozens of other professional disciplines, Pensacola Beach stands to lose millions this summer.

properties.name: Pensacola, FL
properties.description: Pensacola relies heavily, like many other coastal Gulf cities, on tourism that begins in February and runs until the end of summer. Unfortunately that boom has not come this summer and likely will not occur any time soon. Bruce Parris, owner of the beachside restaurant The Dock, reported an 80% loss of business over the July 4th weekend. Usually, "we can’t see our beautiful white sand because of all the towels and bodies out there enjoying the beach," Parris told Fox-10 News, but also made a point to express his lack of surprise adding, "we communicate with all the hotels and everybody. Their reservations are down. Usually you can’t find a room." Ed Schroeder, who heads up the tourism arm for the Pensacola Bay Area Chamber of Commerce in Florida, said less than 15% of the small businesses in his organization affected by the spill had filed claims. Schroeder also added, "I'm scared to death what June is going to look like."

properties.name: Pinellas County, FL
properties.description: Immediately following the oil spill, Pinellas County reported 960 cancellations in its tourist industry. Since then, the numbers have continued to climb.

properties.name: Santa Rosa Beach, FL
properties.description: Property values on the Florida coast seem to be taking a huge hit in the wake of the spill.Ted and Jeanne Melcher of Santa Rosa Beach sent a letter to NWF Daily News this week saying that the value of their home has plummeted in the weeks since the spill. "About 30 days after the spill, my wife and I were shocked to receive an e-mail from Zillow.com informing us that the value of our house had declined 15 percent, or $87,500, over the previous 30 days. Just a few days ago, we received another e-mail from Zillow.com informing us the value of our house had dropped by another 10.6 percent, or another $53,000.So, since the BP oil spill, our property has depreciated in value by a total of $140,500."

properties.name: SouthCoast USA
properties.description:
SouthCoast USA, a travel agency with locations in Alabama, Florida, Louisiana and Mississippi, has already received a $55 million check from BP which it will use to "maximize the
benefits and exposure of an organized and sustained positive public relations
campaign to alleviate and mitigate damage to our industry resulting from the
spill." Travel agencies have fallen on hard times in the Gulf since the oil spill. The U.S. Travel Association reported that in 2008, domestic and international tourists spent a combined $94.2 billion in the Gulf, or 12% of all travel expenditures in the U.S. However, the U.S. Travel Association reports that this year's tourist season has been dismal at best -- with hotels reporting a 35% decrease in business. They also reported that hotels located hundreds of miles from the coast are experiencing a 15% to 17% decrease in revenue, a sign that the spill's impact on tourism is affecting non-coastal cities as well, reports AOL's DailyFinance.

properties.name: Weems, VA
properties.description: W.E. Kellum Seafood, an oyster shucking plant established in 1948, was forced to close its doors after the Gulf oil spill ruined the harvest. The closing of Kellum on the Virginia coast indicates how far-reaching the effects of the spill have become.
